instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
This is a liquid damaged board stuck at 5V. I have the option to decline repair of this board, so I need to quickly assess if it’s repairable (i.e no bad SMC/CPU/GPU/etc)

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is stuck at 5.2V. 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 3.4V.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 3.8V.
All four CD3215s have all LDOs except <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC</SIGNAL> on UB300 and UB400. No short to ground on the missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPCS</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
If it's only a USB-C controller problem it may turn on from charged battery.
Liquid damage should give you hint on where to look.
Compare diode mode to ground on all LDO outputs of all USB-C controllers.

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
Diode mode readings are comparable across all 4 controllers (0.48-0.51). 

I'm new to the USB-C models. What are the requirements for the releasing 20V from the charger?

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: Did you test what happen with both charger and battery connected?

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: The machine's battery is empty and I have no other way of charging it; I have a replacement battery on order to test this.

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
There is a problem on the USB-C area where no 1V1 LDO present (UB300/400).
Did you compare diode mode readings on all 4 LDO rails of each cheap?

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 3.8V"
On all ports?

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: When I use the USB-C ports on the other side of the board, I get 1.1V on the previously missing LDOs (sorry, I forgot there are 4 ports).

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
Upon further inspection, I noticed that the SMC appears to be off. Some SMC-related signals are below. What should I check next?

<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>: 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL>: 0 (briefly 3.4, then pulled low)
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>: 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL>: 2.8

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 0

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL>: 1.2
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>: 3.0
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL>: 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SDA</SIGNAL>: 3.4

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
4 ports and each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> has 4 LDO rails.
Did you check diode mode readings on all 16?

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
Diode and voltage measurements for LDOs

UB400

    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL>    0.515    1.79
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL>    0.479    1.79
    <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>    0.504    1.1
            
UB300   
    <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL>    0.503    3.39
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL>    0.510    1.8
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL>    0.473    1.8

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>

    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL>    0.515    1.8

    <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>    0.505    1.1
            
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
So you get 1V1 LDO on every port.

Still 3.8V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Remove both F7000/1 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: No, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 0V now. I noticed liquid damage in the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area, which is probably the culprit. But the SMC should turn on independently of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, isn't that right?

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message: SMC communicates with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; which can block the bus, if bad.

threads.title: 2016 MacBook Pro 15” <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V
threads.message:
Update: I replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. The SMC is now on, the charger supplies 20V, and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is working.
Thank you!
